children.value: End-to-end testing is a technique that is widely performed in the web ecosystem with frameworks like
, or maybe with your own custom implementation.

But when it comes to the mobile world, this practice is not that common, and there are several existing solutions to address. I have a theory that most mobile developers think testing mobile applications is hard and requires a lot of setup and configuration, and therefore they just skip it.
The goal of this article is to explain how to implement the end-to-end testing framework
in a React Native application, write a bunch of interaction tests, and, finally, integrate it into your development workflow.
Given the length of this article, I will only focus on the iOS flow. Nevertheless, I plan to release a second part covering Android, too.
A quick introduction to end-to-end testing üìñ
Let‚Äôs take a look at the definition of this testing technique:

End-to-end testing is a technique used to test whether the flow of an application right from start to finish is behaving as expected. The purpose of performing end-to-end testing is to identify system dependencies and to ensure that data integrity is maintained between various system components and systems.‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää

In contrast to unit testing, end-to-end testing tries to cover as much of your application‚Äôs functionality as it can. The more it covers, the more reliable your tests will be. Therefore, it includes all the stages of an application:
Installation of the application (if it‚Äôs necessary)
Expecting events or behaviors to happen
This is how end-to-end testing looks in the browser using
Cypress is able to create an instance of Chrome, run a URL, and then start interacting with the webpage by selecting elements (
At any point in the tests, the developer can
something to happen or to have a specific value. In case all the expectations were true, the result of the test suite will be successful.
The process of testing mobile applications is actually quite similar to the web. Let‚Äôs go thought the previously described steps:
create an instance of an emulator (Android/iOS device)
Depending on the framework this may change, but all of them are using native directives to get the reference of an element (
Using the same functions described before, they can validate values or events that happened
This is how end-to-end testing looks like in mobile using
What is Detox, and why should you pick it?
Detox is an end-to-end framework for mobile apps developed by
, one of the top contributors inside the React Native community. They also maintain amazing projects such as
What I like about this framework is the great abstraction it provides to select and trigger actions on elements. This is how a normal test looks:
As you can see, the syntax is quite readable, and by using async/await, you can write synchronous and easy-to-understand tests. Let‚Äôs jump into the demo!
In case you want to skip the explanation and check the code, I‚Äôll give you the
with the project already bootstrapped and the tests in place.
As the focus of this article is testing and not explaining how to set up React Native, I suggest bootstrapping your project using
, which creates a pretty simple and clean React Native project.
Start by installing the dependency and creating a fresh new project.

~ npm install react-native -g
~ react-native init testReactNativeDetox

  Run instructions for iOS:
    ‚Ä¢ cd testReactNativeDetox && react-native run-ios
    - or -
    ‚Ä¢ Open testReactNativeDetox/ios/testReactNativeDetox.xcworkspace in Xcode or run "xed -b ios"
    ‚Ä¢ Hit the Run button

  Run instructions for Android:
    ‚Ä¢ Have an Android emulator running (quickest way to get started), or a device connected.
    ‚Ä¢ cd testReactNativeDetox && react-native run-android
After this step, you can try running the application in the emulator by executing:
Before jumping into testing, you need to have the following
brew tap wix/brew; brew install applesimutils;
Start by adding Detox as a dev dependency for the project.
Inside the CLI, they provide a command that can automatically set up the project. You need to run:

~ detox init -r jest

detox[34202] INFO: [init.js] Created a file at path: e2e/config.json
detox[34202] INFO: [init.js] Created a file at path: e2e/init.js
detox[34202] INFO: [init.js] Created a file at path: e2e/firstTest.spec.js
detox[34202] INFO: [init.js] Patching package.json at path: /Users/USERNAME/Git/testReactNativeDetox/package.json
detox[34202] INFO: [init.js] json["detox"]["test-runner"] = "jest";
This will create a new folder called
with a basic test and some initial configuration such as
, which is the file that tells jest to start the simulator and so on. Let‚Äôs modify this initial test to check if the two first sections are visible.
Next, you need to add a configuration for Detox inside your
. Add the following object to the
with the name of your application:
Once done, try to build the application by running:
In case your build failed with the message
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
and try running the command again.
Finally, time to run the test!

~ detox test

 PASS e2e/firstTest.spec.js (7.514s)
  Example
    ‚úì should have "Step One" section (260ms)
    ‚úì should have "See Your Changes" section (278ms)
Let‚Äôs put those boring and flat sections inside a colorful carousel! Because who doesn‚Äôt love them?
In order to save time, I decided to use an existing carousel component built by the community. For this demo, I used
. I‚Äôm sure there must be better alternatives out there, but this one was the perfect match for my needs.
Also, in order to generate nice random colors, I used
Install both libraries as dependencies for the project:
Then I made a few modifications inside
. This is the summary of changes:
Wrap each section inside a custom
component to the last two slides
In order to make things easier, let‚Äôs add two new
Now that the application has changed, you need to create a new build of it in order to run tests with the modified version. Execute the following command:
This process may take some time. In the meantime, let‚Äôs take a quick look at the existing tests:

The second test will definitely fail because the ‚ÄúSee Your Changes‚Äù section is now in the second slide of the Carousel, which is not visible for the user until they swipe. Therefore, let‚Äôs make Detox move to that slide!
At this point, you can execute the end-to-end tests, and they should pass! The command is:

~ yarn e2e:test

 PASS e2e/firstTest.spec.js (7.514s)
  Example
    ‚úì should have "Step One" section (260ms)
    ‚úì should render "See Your Changes" in the second slide (993ms)
Let‚Äôs add a few more tests to cover the following scenarios:
Test that the carousel allows the user to move back and forth inside the slides.
Move the third slide and interact with the
Move the last slice and interact with the
Feature fully tested! Let‚Äôs run the tests again.

~ yarn e2e:test

 PASS e2e/firstTest.spec.js (22.128s)
  Example
    ‚úì should have "Step One" section (268ms)
    ‚úì should render "See Your Changes" in the second slide (982ms)
    ‚úì should enable swiping back and forth (1861ms)
    ‚úì should render "Debug" and have a Button to click in the third slide (2710ms)
    ‚úì should render "Learn More" and change text in the fourth slide (9964ms)
Bonus: Running E2E test in CI üéÅ

Running tests inside CI is quite important; they basically eliminate the need to do manual testing and prevent shipping bugs to production (in case we have the proper set of tests). For this example, I decided to use
because it has an amazing integration with GitHub and also provides an unlimited plan for open source projects.
In case you are using GitHub, you can install the
, create a new plan, and allow it to access your repositories.
After that, you need to create a new file inside your project called
, which defines the steps you want to run in CI.
I tweaked the CI configuration inside the
a little bit, and this is the one that works in my case.

language: objective-c
osx\_image: xcode10.2

branches:
  only:
    - master

env:
  global:
    - NODE\_VERSION=stable

install:
  - brew tap wix/brew
  - brew install applesimutils
  - curl -o- [https://raw.githubusercontent.com/creationix/nvm/v0.33.2/install.sh](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/creationix/nvm/v0.33.2/install.sh) | bash
  - export NVM\_DIR="$HOME/.nvm" && [-s "$NVM\_DIR/nvm.sh"] && . "$NVM\_DIR/nvm.sh"
  - nvm install $NODE\_VERSION
  - nvm use $NODE\_VERSION
  - nvm alias default $NODE\_VERSION

  - npm install -g react-native-cli
  - npm install -g detox-cli
  - npm install
  - cd ios; pod install; cd -;

script:
  - npm run e2e:ci
One last thing: add the command
. This command will build the application (
), and close the emulator in order to finish the execution (
Once you pushed all the changes into your
branch, try to open a new pull request. You should see a new pull request checker has been added, which will call Travis, and this one runs the Detox tests.
is the link to the full log in Travis for that pull request.

In case you were thinking of adding tests to your React Native application, I highly encourage you to go and try Detox! Detox is an amazing end-to-end testing solution for mobile, and after using it for quite some time, these are the pros and cons:
‚úÖ Very well abstracted syntax for matchers and to trigger specific actions
‚úÖ Integration with Jest is just wonderful
‚úÖ Possibility to run tests in CI
‚ùå Sometimes you might encounter configuration errors, and finding the proper solution may take some time. The best way to address this problem is to go and take a deep look at the
